description: From Middle English seely, sēlī, from Old English sǣliġ, ġesǣliġ (“lucky, fortunate”), from Proto-West Germanic *sālīg, from *sāli. Equivalent to seel (“happiness, bliss”) +‎ -y. Doublet of Seelie.

The semantic evolution is “lucky” → “innocent” → “naïve” → “foolish”. Compare the similar evolution of daft (originally meaning “accommodating”), and almost the reverse with nice (originally meaning “ignorant”).

definitionGroups.group: Laughable or amusing through foolishness or a foolish appearance.

examples: He cannot achieve celebrity by covering himself with diamonds... or by giving a silly price for a hack.
The sylyman lay and herde,And hys wyf answerd.
... thrie Saturdayes befor Lambas and thrie efter called the six silie Saturdayes.

definitionGroups.group: (now chiefly Scotland and Northern England, rare) Pitiful, inspiring compassion, particularly:

entries.meaning: (now literary) Innocent; suffering undeservedly, especially as an epithet of lambs and sheep.
examples: There is no best in þe word, I wene...That suffuris halfe so myche teneAs doth þe sylly wat.

entries.meaning: Insignificant, worthless, (chiefly Scotland) especially with regard to land quality.
examples: Ane sillie scheill vnder ane erdfast stane

entries.meaning: Weak, frail; flimsy (use concerning people and animals is now obsolete).
examples: Here we see that a smal sillie Bird knoweth how to match with so great a Beast.
To doe the thing we canTo please...This silly sickly man.

definitionGroups.group: (now rural UK, rare) Simple, plain, particularly:

examples: Dauid had no more but a sylie slynge, and a few stones.
The silly herdman all astonnied standes.
From Hell (of which the silly people of the Country think the top of this hill to be the mouth).
Wee sillie soules, take the matter too too heauily.
Fow ȝellow ȝellow wes hir heid bot scho of lufe wes sillie.
You say you were knocked silly—was that so?

entries.meaning: (cricket, of a fielding position) Very close to the batsman, facing the bowler; closer than short.
examples: Carpenter now placed himself at silly-point for Grundy, who was playing very forward.

entries.meaning: (now regional or colloquial) Sillily: in a silly manner.
examples: If you did but see how silly a Man fumbles for an Excuse, when he's a little asham'd of being in Love.
While they, poor sillies, bid good night,O' love an' bogles eerie.

entries.meaning: (endearing, gently derogatory) A term of address.
